speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: SCENE II. The DUKE OF LANCASTER'S palace.

speaker: KING RICHARD II
text_entry: Enter JOHN OF GAUNT with DUCHESS

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Alas, the part I had in Woodstock's blood

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Doth more solicit me than your exclaims,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To stir against the butchers of his life!

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: But since correction lieth in those hands

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Which made the fault that we cannot correct,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Put we our quarrel to the will of heaven;

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Who, when they see the hours ripe on earth,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Will rain hot vengeance on offenders' heads.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Finds brotherhood in thee no sharper spur?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Hath love in thy old blood no living fire?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Edward's seven sons, whereof thyself art one,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Were as seven vials of his sacred blood,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Or seven fair branches springing from one root:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Some of those seven are dried by nature's course,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Some of those branches by the Destinies cut;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But Thomas, my dear lord, my life, my Gloucester,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: One vial full of Edward's sacred blood,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: One flourishing branch of his most royal root,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Is crack'd, and all the precious liquor spilt,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Is hack'd down, and his summer leaves all faded,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: By envy's hand and murder's bloody axe.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Ah, Gaunt, his blood was thine! that bed, that womb,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That metal, that self-mould, that fashion'd thee

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Made him a man; and though thou livest and breathest,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Yet art thou slain in him: thou dost consent

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In some large measure to thy father's death,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In that thou seest thy wretched brother die,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Who was the model of thy father's life.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Call it not patience, Gaunt; it is despair:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: In suffering thus thy brother to be slaughter'd,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Thou showest the naked pathway to thy life,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Teaching stern murder how to butcher thee:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That which in mean men we intitle patience

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Is pale cold cowardice in noble breasts.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: What shall I say? to safeguard thine own life,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: The best way is to venge my Gloucester's death.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: God's is the quarrel; for God's substitute,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: His deputy anointed in His sight,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Hath caused his death: the which if wrongfully,

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Let heaven revenge; for I may never lift

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: An angry arm against His minister.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Where then, alas, may I complain myself?

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: To God, the widow's champion and defence.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Why, then, I will. Farewell, old Gaunt.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Thou goest to Coventry, there to behold

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Our cousin Hereford and fell Mowbray fight:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: O, sit my husband's wrongs on Hereford's spear,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: That it may enter butcher Mowbray's breast!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Or, if misfortune miss the first career,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Be Mowbray's sins so heavy in his bosom,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: They may break his foaming courser's back,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And throw the rider headlong in the lists,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: A caitiff recreant to my cousin Hereford!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Farewell, old Gaunt: thy sometimes brother's wife

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With her companion grief must end her life.

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: Sister, farewell; I must to Coventry:

speaker: JOHN OF GAUNT
text_entry: As much good stay with thee as go with me!

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Yet one word more: grief boundeth where it falls,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Not with the empty hollowness, but weight:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I take my leave before I have begun,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: For sorrow ends not when it seemeth done.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Commend me to thy brother, Edmund York.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Lo, this is all:--nay, yet depart not so;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Though this be all, do not so quickly go;

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: I shall remember more. Bid him--ah, what?--

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: With all good speed at Plashy visit me.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Alack, and what shall good old York there see

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: But empty lodgings and unfurnish'd walls,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Unpeopled offices, untrodden stones?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: And what hear there for welcome but my groans?

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Therefore commend me; let him not come there,

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: To seek out sorrow that dwells every where.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Desolate, desolate, will I hence and die:

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: The last leave of thee takes my weeping eye.

speaker: DUCHESS
text_entry: Exeunt
